message.content:
<<<api>>>: Activity.setContentView
<<<code>>>: @Override
public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
    super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
    setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);
    Button button1 = (Button) findViewById(R.id.button1);
    Button button2 = (Button) findViewById(R.id.button2);

    button1.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {
        @Override
        public void onClick(View v) {
            Intent intent = new Intent(MainActivity.this, SecondActivity.class);
            intent.putExtra("buttonNumber", "1");
            startActivity(intent);
        }
    });

    button2.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {
        @Override
        public void onClick(View v) {
            Intent intent = new Intent(MainActivity.this, SecondActivity.class);
            intent.putExtra("buttonNumber", "2");
            startActivity(intent);
        }
    });
}

// In SecondActivity
@Override
public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
    super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
    setContentView(R.layout.activity_second);
    TextView textView = (TextView) findViewById(R.id.textView);

    String buttonNumber = getIntent().getStringExtra("buttonNumber");
    textView.setText(buttonNumber);
}
<<<explanation>>>: In the main activity, we have two buttons. When either button is clicked, it starts a new activity (SecondActivity) and passes a string extra with the intent. The string extra is either "1" or "2", depending on which button was clicked. In the second activity, we retrieve the string extra from the intent and set it as the text of a TextView. This way, if button 1 was clicked in the main activity, the TextView in the second activity will display "1", and if button 2 was clicked, it will display "2".
